title: What would you really like to be invented? - Quora

response.answer_text: Body modification. Specifically, preventing the effects of aging and staying youthful, as well as being able to regenerate at a cellular level from physical injuries. A way to achieve immortality is probably better off not being invented because someday the universe itself will end and you don't wanna be there when it happens (or do you…? Well, most people don't) If we could only regenerate…well not everyone, it should be a luxury for the unfortunate and the rich only. It should be for people who lose limbs or organs in an accident, or for the rich who can afford such an amazing, innovative technology. The body is too fragile. As I type, I'm walking up the stairs. If I fall, I risk hitting my head and dying. What the fuck? I'm not dealing with that shit. The body is too vulnerable and it's annoying. I'm counting on some crazy genius out there to find a way for us to be able to regenerate. Naturally, the effects of aging are not desirable, so I don't like them. I often go to the skatepark to skate (duh) and I see people as I go, because it's near a neighborhood. There's so many old people, frail, fragile, weak, hardly able to walk, watching me skate down the street. Their lives are pretty much over, and they're physically incapable of exploring the world and having fun. It hurts me. They have a conscience. Don't they want to skate, or skydive, or ride a bike, or simply..run? Age takes away your young appearance, your healthy lifestyle, your hobbies, your memory, your sight, your hearing, and most importantly, it takes you away from your family. I've lost my great grandmother like this. I hadn't seen her since I was a child, and now being an early teen, I never got to speak to her again. An old fossil like her who was nearly 100 years old, who knows how long it had been since she could enjoy a good jog in a park. I think I've made my point. The human body is weak, vulnerable, and it's best weapon is the brain. Only the brain can hope to accomplish a way to make up for how weak our bodies are. I am confident someone will invent this kind of technology before I grow senile as an elder. Aging is nature's greatest curse. As we've done before with so many obstacles, we will overcome this one eventually too.

A weapon of some kind which was reasonably cheap to manufacture and easy to use, and which would knock people out as fast and from as great a distance as a gun would do, without causing permanent damage. The dart guns we use for wildlife won’t do, because the dart sometimes bounces off, they’re dose-critical, and they take a couple of minutes to knock the target out. But there are already sleeping drugs on which it’s almost impossible to overdose - the more you take the longer you sleep, but you don’t die - so it just needs faster action and a reliable delivery system. That’s the only way I can see that the US could get out of the cycle of “I need a gun to defend myself because I’m scared of you because you have a gun”, and then the only people who would need a *lethal* weapon would be those hunting for meat or pest-control or to cull over-populated species.

At the end of the day you would go back home and while you’re relaxing and having a drink, it would take you to a nice restaurant. Finally, at the end of the night it would take you out of town to recharge where the energy is cheap, flush out the tanks, empty the trash, reload fresh water, pick up mail, etc. and on Friday night it would move to the beach for the weekend. Telephone. It stays on a stand in your house so it never gets broken or lost. It has no screens and no memory capability so your conversations remain private. And you have to use your brain to remember friends’ phone numbers. Or write them down. Your brain: use it or lose it. A “box” that you put stuff you don’t want into. You hand write whatever you know about the item on a sticky note attached to it. When it’s full you carry it to the curb and It summons a truck that injects the box with foam for transport, then picks it up and takes it to a warehouse. Everything is photographed in very high resolution from many angles by a robot. Then each item is listed online with the photos and your sticky note, for a fixed price, and the price goes down every day. At the end of one year, everything unsold is donated to a charity. You get either the selling price less a commission, or a tax receipt for the donation. The starting price is on the box you put things in. There are $20, $50, $100, $500, and $1000 boxes.

Original Question: Which invention do you wish you had invented? Answer: Drop Ceilings (with the patent). That guy changed business interior design and made sooo much money. More interesting question: If you could finish developing one technology and/or invention that is currently under develop, what would it be. You get credit for its discovery, you may or may not get the patent and the attached royalties. Answer: With this more interesting question, I would be torn between cellular printers (large 3-D printers that work with custom grown cells to create genetically identical replacement parts for humans) or Entangled Particle cards. Cellular printers would allow any part of a person (with the notable exception of the Brain) to be reprinted with their own cells and then reattached/replaced through surgery. Hopefully, our understanding of neurology would also continue, but if it didn’t, we would still be able to replace most major organ failures and accident induced loses with no need for donors or anti-rejection drugs. With Entangled Particle cards, we would could create trillions of cards the size of micro-SD cards with thin sheets of Entangled Particles where there are hundreds/thousands of pairs and one half of each pair is on one card and the other half of each pair is on the other card. Then, one card is given to a telecommunications company and the other goes into your phone/computer/etc. Entangled Particles utilized Einstein’s “Spooky action”, with both particles of a pair of Entangled Particles behaving as it they were next to each other regardless of the distance. Using this technology in this manner, communication between the device and the telecommunications service is nearly instantaneous with no issues caused by ‘power lines’, ‘distance from the nearest cell tower’, ‘being in a tunnel or large building’, etc. Instantaneous and clear. You can maintain a large server / server farm and everyone who is on the same server would also have nearly perfect communication. Put all of the server farms for all of the large telecoms in the same basic area and it won’t be long before they are all connected with state of the art communication lines that add only milliseconds to any data transfer. Transform some of the servers from mere telecom servers to computational servers and phones/laptops/tablets could suddenly behave as if they were super-computers (reducing what needs to be onboard to the minimum and using the servers chips as their own.) This would allow companies to build tiny, handheld medical devices that use the processing power of the corporations’ giant server/computer half a world away. Medical costs would drop through-out the world. Tablet and phone prices would drop. Data transfers would be done at bus speeds, not wireless. Phones could be small and carried by everyone, while working in cities or remote areas (making it much easier to find people who get abandoned/lost/kidnapped). Communications would still be nearly instantaneous, even when talking to people on Mars or another solar system. It would redefine how we treat computers/software.

An APP THAT WILL LOCK OUT requests to “update” cell phones. People keep getting update messages ad nauseam on a regular basis, often as many as two or three times a week. Each time you are given a choice, “update” (or “carrier update”) or “cancel.” People keep pressing “cancel” nearly every time. It’s irritating. But it can be much worse than irritating. Every once in a while, one’s finger accidentally hits the “update.” Once that happens, there is NO “undo” button to back out. He is faced with a long menu of hoops to jump, passwords to input and spending considerable time. Finally, once the update is completed, certain functions and/or apps don’t work properly. Or worse yet, the update asks for an unknown password or other unknown input. The phone is rendered useless. He can’t make calls or anything. He goes to the place where he bought the phone. The people there can’t help him either. They don’t know the unknown passwords or inputs. He then goes to the nearest Apple HQ (or whatever) which can be dozens of miles away. After a lot of trouble, he can sometimes fix it. Often he cannot. From there, the only option is to buy a new phone. Several people I know have had this problem. They have spent hours, sometimes days, looking for a solution.

A film that is impervious to hydrogen or helium. With such a film we could have dirigibles high up in the atmosphere 24/7. As it is now, these two light gases diffuse quite rapidly through anything - including steel ! So, it’s not possible to have a lighter-than-air balloon permanently up above the Earth for surveillance, exploration or cell phone signal transmission. There are some thick films that resist hydrogen diffusion, but they are too stiff, heavy and brittle for balloon use. Some day, somebody will crack this problem.
